urn:contentItem:5SKK-RG01-JDPT-T4V1-00000-00HOUSE APPROPRIATIONS COMMITTEE MARKUP OF THE F.Y. 2019 DEFENSE APPROPRIATIONS BILL AND THE FINANCIAL SERVICES AND GENERAL GOVERNMENT APPROPRIATIONS BILL, PART 22018-06-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:23ZLexisNexisHOUSE APPROPRIATIONS COMMITTEE MARKUP OF THE F.Y. 2019 DEFENSE APPROPRIATIONS BILL AND THE FINANCIAL SERVICES AND GENERAL GOVERNMENT APPROPRIATIONS BILL, PART 2

June 13, 2018

COMMITTEE HEARING

REP. RODNEY FRELINGHUYSEN

FRELINGHUYSEN: The meeting will come to order. If members could take seats and we're going to begin.

Again, the chair recognizes the gentleman from Mississippi, Mr. Palazzo...

PALAZZO: Mr. Chairman, I have an amendment at the desk.

FRELINGHUYSEN: ... for the purpose of an amendment. You have an amendment at the desk. Would you consider it read? Yes.

PALAZZO: Yes, I ask that it be considered read.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Good. And you're recognized to present your amendment.

PALAZZO: All right.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Please give Mr. Palazzo your attention.

PALAZZO: Mr. Chairman, this is a simple amendment that would increase funding for community development financial institutions, otherwise known as CDFIs. Unfortunately, the committee mark proposed a $59 million reduction in funding from fiscal year 2018 levels.

But with the help of the chairman of the subcommittee and his wonderful staff, we've been able to find a path forward. My amendment would take the first step towards returning these essential funds by reallocating $25 million to make up a part of the shortfall.

For those of you who aren't familiar, CDFI banks take a small amount of public money to leverage private investment in communities that are traditionally underserved with historically high poverty rates.

For every $1 of public investments in CDFIs over $12 of private investment are used to support for small businesses, create jobs and revitalize the most impoverished communities in America.

In addition, they help put millions on the road to buying homes and establishing personal financial security. They also provide essential financial literacy education to their customers. I know many of you on this committee represent areas with high poverty rates.

CDFIs are active in your communities and are essential sources of banking for many of our most underserved. I ask my colleagues to support the amendment and I yield back the balance of my time.

ROGERS: Will the gentleman yield before you...

FRELINGHUYSEN: The gentleman yield to the chairman, Mr. Rogers.

ROGERS: Will the gentleman yield?

PALAZZO: Yield to the chairman.

ROGERS: I'd like to identify myself with the gentleman's remarks. It's a great amendment. The CDFIs are vitally important in poor areas like mine and perhaps yours. And I would urge that we pass the gentleman's amendment. I yield.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thanks the gentleman.

Mr. Graves is recognized.

GRAVES: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. And I want to thank, Mr. Palazzo and Chairman Rogers for their positive comments. I rise to accept the amendment. These increases -- as he referenced, the CDFI funds financial and technical assistance grants by $25 million, taking it to a total level of $216 million.

And let me remind the committee that is $202 million above the president's request. The administration initially requested $14 million. I know this committee's commitment is to rural communities throughout our country. And this will assist in that way. So I want to thank, Mr. Palazzo and his commitment here and I look forward to accepting the amendment.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Further discussion? Mr. Palazzo, you have an -- a minute. You don't have to take it to close.

PALAZZO: Well, thank you, Mr. Chairman. In the interest of time I will keep it brief. Please support my amendment. I yield back.

FRELINGHUYSEN: OK. The question is on the Palazzo amendment. All those in favor, say aye. All those opposed, say nay.

In the opinion of the chair, the ayes have it.

Ms. Pingree is recognized, gentlewoman from Maine.

PINGREE: Thank you very much, Mr. Chair. I have an amendment at the desk, Pingree Number 1.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Yes. Let me say that last amendment was adopted. I apologize. And your amendment is considered read and you're recognized. Excuse me.

PINGREE: Thank you. First, I want to thank the chair and the subcommittee for recognizing the importance of giving the executive branch authorities to combat corruption and to punish human rights abusers around the world.

I'm pleased that the Bill adds $2 million to the Treasury Department's Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence, which handles sanctions investigation and enforcement. I'm also pleased that the report language stresses the need for resources to be directed towards Africa, including to address protracted conflicts in Sudan, South Sudan, and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

It also calls for robust implementation of the Global Magnitsky Act sanctions on corruption in human rights. Currently, there are only five sanctions investigators assigned to the team, responsible for designations and delistings for all Africa sanctions programs as well as Global Magnitsky in Venezuela.

Too often these staffers are pulled away to deal with emerging issues like Iran. My amendment would add an additional $2.9 million to create nine new positions with the relevant offices at Treasury to accomplish this goal. Recognizing that the bill already includes an increase, I'm willing to withdraw my amendment and happy to work with the chair going forward.

Will the chair attempt to increase -- support this increase as we move toward conference to ensure that additional resources for Treasury go to the needs identified in the report such as nations in conflict in Central and East Africa and for the global Magnitsky Act?

FRELINGHUYSEN: We'll -- Chairman Graves.

GRAVES: Mr. Chairman, I want to thank the gentlewoman from Maine for raising this issue. It's an issue I think we're all committed to. Government sanctions, abuses of human rights around the world is on the rise.

I look forward to working with you in the days ahead and also with Chairman Rogers and his subcommittee as well. But thank you, again, for your interest in this issue and your commitment.

PINGREE: Thank you. And thank you for being willing to work on this. Just to make sure it's clear. I have people from the Sudan, South Sudan, Burundi in my state. And often those smaller countries are the ones that never get these enforced and there just aren't enough people to do it.

So I know you understand that. I just wanted to help make that point clear. And I hope that there is potential for additional funding if we can find a way to work in it together. And I withdraw my amendment and thank you for your consideration.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank you. The amendment has been withdrawn.

Recognize Dr. Harris for the purpose of an amendment.

HARRIS: Thanks very much, Mr. Chairman. I have an administration at the desk.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Would you consider it read?

HARRIS: And yes, I move to dispense with the reading.

FRELINGHUYSEN: So ordered and the gentleman is recognized.

HARRIS: Mr. Chairman, this amendment follows up on what you talked about in your opening statement, that one important program funded by this bill is the OSP, what is the school program, the school choice program in Washington, D.C.

And it's tremendously successful. Has a waiting list. They could actually move some students into that program from D.C. public school, D.C. charter schools if they had more funding, so what my amendment does is it adds an additional $5 million into their funding, offsetting that by decreasing funding into the public school and charter school part of that program -- of that program spending.

And that way leaves actually more per pupil expenditures for both the public school and the public charter schools while fulfilling an increase in the ability of students to engage in the OSP.

So I offer the amendment and I will -- I've spoken to the chairman of the subcommittee. He's agreed to work on getting that funding increased, so I will intend to withdraw the amendment.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank you, doctor.

Mr. Graves.

GRAVES: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I appreciate Dr. Harris's commitment to children and providing the best education. You're absolutely right, I agree with you on the impact this has had in the past and look forward to working with you in the days ahead to make sure we're impacting lives in a positive way as children are being educated in this area. Thank you.

HARRIS: So I withdraw the amendment, Mr. Chairman.

FRELINGHUYSEN: OK. Thank you both.

Mr. Joyce, amendment number 2. You have two amendments.

JOYCE: Yes, I do. And I appreciate this opportunity to speak, Mr. Chairman. I have that amendment at the desk. And I ask...

FRELINGHUYSEN: Would you consider it read?

JOYCE: ... consider as read. Yes.

FRELINGHUYSEN: And you are recognized on your second amendment.

JOYCE: I thank you very much, Mr. Chairman. My amendment would reverse the 2015 decision by the United States Postal Service to its lower delivery service standards for first class mail and periodicals.

Since these standards are lower, timely processing and delivery of the mail has been significantly degraded across the country. Mail delays are dragging down our business and I'm sure I'm not alone in saying that my constituents have noticed the effects of late mail.

I hear it all the time. Medications aren't arriving in a timely fashion. (inaudible) pay your bill on time, if the bills arrive late, so in turn they receive a late fee payment. Invitations get lost, especially to my house.

And weekly newspapers arrive a week late. And importantly, absentee balances are arriving late and at this point it's unlikely the United States Postal Service can guarantee a timely delivery for elections this spring and next November.

So, although, the Postal Service reduction of standards was intended to save money, the consolidation plan actually cost money for fiscal year 2015. The Postal Service spent $130 million on increased transportation costs as a result of the closures and lost a total of $66 million due to the consolidation plan.

I therefore urge my colleagues to vote in favor of this amendment to restore the postal standards to those that were in effect in July 1st, 2012, so all of our constituents may receive the service they depend on.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank you, Mr. Joyce.

Mr. Graves?

GRAVES: Mr. Chairman, unfortunately, I have to raise an opposition to the amendment, but not to my good friend, Mr. Joyce personally. But the amendment -- and he and I have had a discussion about this. His intentions are well, but clearly this has a direct impact on the Postal Service. I think it's a $1.5 billion negative impact on the Postal Service. I truly respect and understand the gentleman's concern about the service standards.

JOYCE: Thank you.

GRAVES: And look forward to working with you in the days ahead, hopefully along with OGR, the committee of jurisdiction. But because of the high cost of this one amendment, it's a tremendous cost I would have to oppose, the amendment only but not the gentleman.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Ms. Kaptur, I understand is recognized to talk on this amendment.

KAPTUR: I would like to rise in support of the gentleman's amendment and implore the chair and the ranking member to try to really look at this. I don't think that the -- whoever did this for the Postal Service was really thinking.

And their decision to eliminate overnight service for first-class mail and even the manner in which our mail arrives now, this has never happened before but an envelope will be in an envelope. Something was ripped because it was sent up to Pontiac, Michigan out of Ohio, let's say.

And really there have been a lot of delays. What Congressman Joyce talks about medicine that is true. And there is something really wrong with the way this routing is going and degrading our mail standards has impacted the timely delivery of everything from medicines to greeting cards, bill payments to business mail, personal letters to government correspondence, not to mention local election mail.

The timely processing delivery of mail is really critical. And the Postal Service delivers 154 billion pieces of mail annually to 155 million delivery points, accounting for 47 percent of the world's mail.

It's an enormous undertaking that equals over 2000 percent more in terms of business than either the UPS or FedEx. The Postal Service serves everyone and they have admitted that their decision to reduce delivery standards has cost the agency $66 million in losses due to added transportation cost, in 2015, $130 million alone.

So this isn't even a very wise business decision. So, I would really implore the chair to keep working with us. I think we should exercise our authority. They've had trouble appointing people to the board of the Postal Service, whoever heard of that.

And the future of our public Postal Service is threatened by delayed mail and it harms small business. It harms people in rural America. And we really have to exercise our authority here. So, I urge my colleagues to support our Postal Service, Mr. Joyce's amendment.

And I would really urge the chairman somehow to work with us as we move toward the floor, if he can't accept this now and would urge my colleagues to vote for the Joyce amendment. And I yield back.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Mr. Quigley on the Joyce amendment.

QUIGLEY: Sure. Mr. Chairman, I rise in strong support of this bipartisan amendment to restore mail delivery service standards to 2012 levels. Every year millions of Americans rely on the USPS to provide affordable, efficient mail delivery service. And in many communities USPS is the only affordable option to send and receive mail. Over the last year, I've received countless Postal Service complaints on slow and inconsistent mail service in my district.

This includes delayed mail, sometimes taking weeks to arrive due to bad weather or unscheduled employee absences, wrongly delivered mail, and severely damaged mail. Americans have come to expect timey and dependable mail service. And we need to make sure that the Post Office is maintaining its high standards, therefore I support this amendment and urge my colleagues to vote in favor.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Further discussion on the Joyce amendment? If (ph) -- hearing none, Mr. Joyce has a minute to close.

JOYCE: Why, thank you, Mr. Chairman. U.S. mail system is an important part of our nation's infrastructure, connecting people of all communities with the institutions that serve them. I urge my colleagues to support this amendment. And I thank you, again, Mr. Chairman. And yield back the balance of my time.

FRELINGHUYSEN: OK. The question is on the Joyce amendment. All those in favor, say aye. All those opposed, say nay.

Got you. You find this humorous. I think the ayes got it. The amendment is approved. At least you got one approved today.

JOYCE: I know it's much to your chagrin, sir.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Mr. Price?

Mr. Price is recognized for the purpose of an amendment.

Mr. Price has an amendment at the desk.

PRICE: I have an amendment at the desk. I ask that its reading be dispensed with.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Considered it done. The gentleman is recognized.

PRICE: Mr. Chairman, I have an amendment offered in partnership with Mr. Serrano that would restore net neutrality protections that entrepreneurs, small businesses, and the public rely on over the use of internet.

I am sure all of us here know that net neutrality is a term used to describe the principle that all content travelling over the internet should be treated equally by the owners of the networks providing internet service to customers.

Since its inception, the internet has allowed anyone with an internet connection to access or to provide information, goods or services on a relatively equal footing. This open design has been largely responsible for the revolutionary impact that the internet has had on global commerce, innovation and information sharing in so many other aspects of our daily lives.

Yet, in recent years, some companies have openly defied these bedrock open internet principles. There are well-documented examples of internet service providers deliberately throttling broadband speed when consumers try to connect to certain applications, blocking content from competitors and providing preferential treatment to their own content.

So in 2015, after several years of legal battles and careful deliberation, the FCC issued its revised open internet order. These rules enshrined in federal regulation the basic principle of net neutrality, that the companies that provide internet service to consumers to offer that service in an open and nondiscriminatory manner.

This principle is supported by the major tech companies, entrepreneurs, small businesses, research universities, librarians, local governments, a large majority of Americans, nearly everybody, in fact except the companies that provide these commercial internet services.

And yet, despite receiving millions of consumer comments supporting net neutrality, the FCC suddenly voted last year to overturn net neutrality, eroding the principles of openness, innovation and fairness that are the cornerstone of the internet.

Citizens are paying attention to this issue. I expect all of us can attest to that. I received 14,000 letters and e-mails on this subject in this Congress alone. On Monday, these FCC net neutrality protections officially lapsed. The Senate has already voted to overturn the FCC's net neutrality repeal. And this amendment presents us with the opportunity to do the same. So let's put our constituents, small businesses and entrepreneurs first by restoring net neutrality. I urge support for this amendment.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank you, Mr. Price.

Mr. Graves?

GRAVES: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I would have to rise in opposition to the amendment. I think we can all agree on the desire for a free and open internet. And we all do, in fact, it is. I just heard that the gentleman received 14,000 e-mails in opposition to the rule. Apparently, the internet is open and it's free. And people are expressing their opinions. That's what we want and that's what we desire.

But this amendment will just restore things back to the old rule and prohibit FCC from issuing any other rules. In fact, it's circumventing the whole process of public comments and the openness and transparency that we all desire.

The Senate has taken up this issue. I suspect the House may take it up as well. This is not the right committee or jurisdiction in which to do that. The Internet has been the biggest driving force for innovation in our lifetimes.

This is no time to mess with it in a hearing such as this. It's doing well. Just check your e-mails. You're getting them. So, Mr. Chairman, with that, I'd have to rise in opposition to the amendment.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Ms. Lowey?

LOWEY: Mr. Chairman, I rise in strong support of my friend's amendment. This week despite overwhelming public support, the FCC's repeal of net neutrality protection officially went into effect.

It's an unfortunate step as we know net neutrality protects small businesses, entrepreneurs, students and consumers by ensuring a level playing field online. Paid prioritization means the end of a free and open internet.

Today, we have an opportunity to protect net neutrality, ensure that our constituents choose what websites and apps they can access online. We owe it to our constituents to do everything in our power to fight for their open access.

Please, vote for the amendment. I yield back.

FRELINGHUYSEN: I thank the gentlewoman.

Mr. Serrano, a cosponsor of the amendment, is recognized.

SERRANO: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

I want to thank my good friend from North Carolina, Mr. Price, for working on this issue for so many years. On the net neutrality, we do not see a stifling of creativity in innovation like we were told by the opposition.

In fact, it did the opposite, ushering in a spirit and wave of innovation because more people were able to access an internet that treated all content and data the same. This amendment would simply reinstate the 2015 net neutrality rules that have kept the internet open and fair for all Americans.

It would prevent our constituents from having to pay more to access their favorite websites and streaming services. It will prevent students from having educational content blocked by their ISPs, therefore jeopardizing their learning experience.

And it would prevent small businesses from having their websites throttled and face delays in trying to showcase their products for consumers. While major service providers like Comcast and AT&T have recently announced that they have no plans to prioritize certain web traffic or create paid fast lanes, what is to stop them from changing their minds in the future and raising prices on consumers? Let us not forget that the first priority of any cooperation is to make money. But it should be the responsibility of Congress and the federal government to protect all Americans' ability to access a resource that has become so engrained in our culture and economy.

That is why the principles enshrined in the 2015 net neutrality rules are so important and why tens of millions of Americans strongly support these principles. This is a matter of fairness and equality.

I ask my colleagues to put the interests of families, students, rural and urban Americans and small businesses ahead of corporate interest. I urge a yes vote on the Price Serrano amendment. Thank you.

FRELINGHUYSEN: I thank the gentleman for his comments.

I see Mr. Kilmer and then Mr. Cartwright, Mr. -- OK.

Mr. Taylor, I guess you...

TAYLOR: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Just a couple of things. Number one: obviously, net neutrality in the way it's been framed is inaccurate and deceiving in many ways. And it's kind of embarrassing in some respects as well.

When you look at -- talk about corporate interests and one of the issues here is blocking and throttling, the only folks doing blocking and throttling now are the big tech companies and, of course, they support net neutrality, which would put the ISPs who are not just your Verizons and Cox and stuff like that but 3,000 of them across the nation that provide low cost internet to rural areas, like some in my own district.

And they, of course, would support pushing them to be regulated under a 1930s scheme. So think about that for a second. Companies that are in the internet being regulated under a 1930 scheme, does that really make any sense? I don't think so.

So, of course, the tech companies would support that because they don't want them to get into the data business, which is highly profitable. Look, I think everyone here there's an equality of desire not to have -- to have a level playing field, to not have blocking, to not have throttling. But also to regulate the internet under the same ecosphere, so -- ecosystem, excuse me, so under the FCC, everyone being regulated under the same rules.

And having that opt -- the opt-in -- and our people would have the ability to opt in, and then perhaps look at potential soft regulations on data, on who owns your data. So this is a larger discussion that has to happen, but not here in this committee. So I would oppose it. Thank you.

FRELINGHUYSEN: OK. I thank the gentleman. Mr. Kilmer is recognized and then Mr. Cartwright.

KILMER: Thanks. Thanks, Mr. Chairman. I support this amendment; I support a free and open internet. But we had a debate on the -- on the last bill about the inability of Congress to step in in an area where it ought to use some of its authority. That was with regard to authorization for use of military force.

But I think this is another example where Congress has sort of dropped the ball. You know, this is larger than just one issue. Congress should look at holistically reforming our telecom laws because the last major piece of telecom policy that passed out of Congress was in 1996.

You know, 1996, less than a quarter of Americans were online. The ones that were used Netscape and a dial-up modem. When they got their e-mail, it said, "You've Got Mail." You know, that was seven years before, MySpace, a PalmPilot was thought to be cutting-edge technology at that time.

Someone who used the term smart phone at that time was describing something that weighed more than a pound and was the size of a brick. You know, but because Congress hasn't acted on this, agencies have tried to pick up the slack and that's not the way to go. Rather than seeing this issue decided by agency action, I'd like to see Congress step up and set some rules of the road and pass legislation that comprehensively reforms our telecom and technology policy. To me, it's a competitiveness issue. I think you've heard folks on both sides of the aisle with different perspectives on this, but make the same point that this is important to our businesses, this is about jobs...

TAYLOR: Will the gentleman yield?

KILMER: Yes. Sure.

TAYLOR: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Appreciate the sentiment and I agree with the gentleman that we should -- that Congress should take this up and look at it holistically. But the gentleman mentioned the antiquated action that was taken -- you know, 1996 I guess prior to MySpace. But does the gentleman believe that we should look at regulating a -- you know, the ISPs under a 1930 scheme?

KILMER: So just reclaiming my time. In my view, the issue needs to be decided by Congress rather than just yielding to the executive. I think it's time for Congress to catch up with the rest of the country, bring our laws up to speed with our technology. And I support the amendment but I also support the Congress stepping in and doing something about it.

FRELINGHUYSEN: OK. Further discussion? Mr. Culberson's recognized.

CULBERSON: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I, too, support net neutrality. I want to prevent the internet service providers from throttling access to services for any customer, but I have a real concern this amendment as chairman Graves said, particularly the way it's drafted, that the amendment would prevent the Federal Communications Commission from reissuing a rule in substantially the same form. I'm not sure what substantially means. What -- how is that defined?

So I'm afraid that the -- while we are in agreement I believe with the spirit of what Mr. Price is doing, the amendment itself is not effective, unenforceable, undefinable, and I'm not sure how you'd ever make any sense out of what this amendment proposes to do. So I hope we'll find another opportunity to restore that neutrality but not do it here and do it in a more thoughtful, careful fashion.

FRELINGHUYSEN: I thank the gentleman from Texas for his remarks. Mr. Cartwright from Pennsylvania is recognized.

CARTWRIGHT: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I speak in support of this amendment and I do thank Representatives Price and Serrano for their hard work on this matter. I also wish to associate myself with remarks of Mr. Kilmer. I think the free exchange of information and ideas is an essential principle in this country.

Every single one of our constituents wants net neutrality because they want to be assured they have access, choice, and freedom to get the internet content that they want. As such, I think the American people and the companies affected by this issue deserve some certainty on the matter.

That's why I hope, as Congressman Kilmer said, that, as a Congress, we can soon work in a bipartisan fashion to address this issue legislatively to let our voters know we are listening to their concerns and we are actively engaged on this issue. I urge support of the amendment. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Further discussion on the amendment? Mr. Pocan and then Ms. Lee.

POCAN: Sure. Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman. I think the argument by the subcommittee chairman on this was that so many contacts -- 14,000 contacts proves it works. Well, the rule change just took effect this week so it did work, you're right.

The previous system worked very well. In fact, I had 12,983 contacts as of a month ago that were against the ruling and zero, zero for it. Now, to be fair, I did have a telecommunications lobbyist from my district stop by the other day, and he asked to be counted, so I am now up to 12,983 to 1.

But I think this is very similar in many of our districts. My small business owners don't want us to throttle the internet, my farmers don't want to have fast lanes, and the consumers don't want to. So this is something that the Senate took care of. Now it's in the hands of the House.

We could do a discharge petition, which I hope many of you will sign on to, but I think this is one where people are way, way, way ahead of us on this, and I strongly support this amendment. I thank the gentleman who introduced this and I hope we'll pass it.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank the gentleman for his comments. Further discussion? Ms. Lee is recognized for some comments on the amendment, the Price amendment.

LEE: Thank you very much. Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Let me just associate myself with all the remarks that have been made and say a couple things about our democracy, really, in terms of the blow it's taken as it relates to the FCC rules mandating net neutrality.

This really is equal treatment of all content on the internet, and it was overturned by this new rule imposed by the chairman. Mr. Price's amendment is extremely important because it nullifies this new rule. Internet providers will be able to provide websites from loading or slow them down simply because they disagree with what the website says.

TAYLOR: Will the gentlelady?

LEE: Yes, I'll yield.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Gentleman's -- gentlelady's yielded.

LEE: Yes.

TAYLOR: (inaudible). Will the gentlelady agree -- I think everybody agrees about the blocking and throttling and not stopping websites just because you don't agree with the content from up. Will the gentlelady -- that a lot of that -- some of the content you're speaking of is also from not ISPs, but on social media platforms. Will the gentlelady agree that those should also be regulated in the same ways so as to have that information come out and not be blocked or throttled, which does not -- does not address this amendment?

LEE: Let me reclaim my time please. This is really about freedom of speech and freedom of expression. OK? From entrepreneurs to advocates for social justice, the internet has been a powerful tool for everyone, especially communities of color, to revitalize our neighborhoods and draw attention really to the injustices in our society in order to change them.

And so this new repeal of the open internet rule -- it really kills this free expression and innovation and it kills it online. And it shouldn't be a partisan issue. It's opposed by 86 percent of the public, Democrats and Republicans understand what's at stake. So I urge a yes vote on this amendment.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank you, Ms. Lee. Mr. Ruppersberger has been very patient.

RUPPERSBERGER: Thank you. First, I support this amendment but the one thing that's become very clear to me is this whole process in what we're dealing with now needs to be dealt with with our Congress. The American people clearly feel passionately about this issue and we need to come up with a bipartisan legislative solution, so there is no ambiguity on the regulatory side, and future administrations continue to ping pong back and forth. Democrat and Republican, this issue is not good for American consumers or American businesses. Yield back.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank the gentleman for his comments. A minute to close, Mr. Price is recognized.

PRICE: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. It's interesting to see members raise the bugaboo of regulation and as though there was any option here. We're talking about one FCC regulation versus another. OK? So make your choice.

It's the FCC regulation enacted after great care -- with great care in 2015 that, in fact, protected that level playing field that we all want to see. And I agree with the chairman, it's no time to mess with the internet.

The messing with the internet with this new regulation that overturns that carefully arrived at rule. Many members in this room have embraced the Congressional Review Act in dealing with regulations that they find objectionable over this last year. This takes the form of exactly that.

This is a -- this is a Congressional Review Act type amendment. It reflects what was done on a bipartisan basis in the Senate. It is something where the House needs to step up to the plate. And, for that reason, I urge the support of this amendment.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank you, Mr. Price. The question is on the Price amendment. All those in favor, say aye. All those opposed, say nay.

In the opinion of the chair, the nays have it. The amendment is not agreed. Sufficient hands have been raised, clerk will call the vote.

CLERK: Mr. Aderholt.

ADERHOLT: No.

CLERK: Mr. Aderholt, no.

Mr. Aguilar.

AGUILAR: Aye.

CLERK: Mr. Aguilar, aye.

Mr. Amodei. Mr. Amodei.

Mr. Bishop.

BISHOP: Yes.

CLERK: Mr. Bishop, yes.

Mr. Calvert.

CALVERT: No.

CLERK: Mr. Calvert, no.

Mr. Carter.

CARTER: No.

CLERK: Mr. Carter, no.

Mr. Cartwright.

CARTWRIGHT: Aye.

CLERK: Mr. Cartwright, aye.

Ms. Clark.

CLARK: Aye.

CLERK: Ms. Clark, aye.

Mr. Cole.

COLE: No.

CLERK: Mr. Cole, no.

Mr. Cuellar.

CUELLAR: Yes.

CLERK: Mr. Cuellar yes.

Mr. Culberson.

CULBERSON: No.

CLERK: Mr. Culberson, no.

Ms. DeLauro.

DELAURO: Aye.

CLERK: Ms. DeLauro, aye.

Mr. Diaz-Balart. Mr. Diaz-Balart.

JOYCE: Well, thank you, Mr. Chairman. I have an amendment at the desk and ask that it be considered as read.

FRELINGHUYSEN: It's considered read and the gentleman's recognized.

JOYCE: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. My amendment -- my amendment simply put prohibits penalization of financial institutions solely because the institution provides financial services to an entity that involves a properly-registered state-compliant marijuana-related company.

To be clear, the business or entity must be operating within the laws of the state to avoid penalization. This is not about whether or not one approves of marijuana. This is about public safety and financial transparency.

While 46 states, 3 territories and the district now allow cannabis-related businesses to operate, our banks and credit unions cannot provide financial services to them. Strangely enough, ATMs are allowed inside dispensaries so one may withdraw funds from their bank to make a purchase in cash.

The situation is untenable. No industry can operate safely and transparently without access to banks or other financial institutions. To ensure these legitimate going concerns are safe, legitimate, and operating completely within the laws of the licensing state, we must allow them access to the financial system. I urge support of my amendment in the interests of financial transparency and public safety and reserve the balance of my time.

FRELINGHUYSEN: I thank the gentleman. Chairman Graves.

QUIGLEY: I was tempted to say the opponents of this are dazed and confused, but I'll hold back. I do rise in support of the Joyce amendment. When I think of an all-cash operation, I think of the mob or a cartel, not a legal, regulated business. We are effectively telling these businesses that they should operate like the black market, encouraging obscurity rather than transparency.

Additionally, by denying legal businesses access to banking services such as credit card processing and deposit revenues, a public safety risk is created. Recent headlines demonstrate this risk, reporting of robberies, home invasions, and other threats associated with possessing large sums of cash.

Regardless how each of us may view the legalization of marijuana, I think we all agree that financial institutions should be allowed to serve businesses that are operating legitimately. I urge my colleagues to support this amendment, which respects states' rights and prioritizes public safety.

RYAN: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Section 818 is a new provision prohibiting federal and local funds from being used to carry out the Reproductive Health Non-Discrimination Amendment Act or RHNDA, a law passed by the D.C. Council in 2014. RHNDA protects employees working in the District of Columbia from workplace discrimination based on their reproductive health decisions and those of their spouses and dependents.

Under this law, an employer cannot fire a woman for having an abortion after a rape or for using in vitro fertilization to address infertility. It prohibits an employer from reducing the salary of a man who uses condoms for family planning or a parent who buys birth control for a son or daughter in college.

As written, section 818 prohibits the District of Columbia from using any funds including local funds consisting solely of local taxes and fees to carry out RHNDA. This provision represents the sixth attempt by Congress to undermine this nondiscrimination law since 2015, but the first time this RHNDA rider has been included in the underlying financial services appropriations bill.

Unlike the D.C. Council, no member of this committee or this Congress was elected to legislate on local D.C. issues. The inclusion of section 818 is undemocratic, a violation of the majority stated belief, and local control, and autonomy, and yet another insult to D.C. residents, some of whom are staffers, their spouses, and their children. To remedy this, my amendment inserts federal before funds, restoring the District of Columbia's ability to spend its local funds to carry out RHNDA's mission.

In anticipation of possible objections to my amendment, let me be clear about what RHNDA does not do. It does not discriminate against churches or religious organizations. It applies to all employers, and the law protects religious liberty by ensuring every employee in D.C. can follow his or her religious or moral beliefs when making health care decisions without fear of retaliation.

It does not force employers to cover elective abortions in their health insurance plans. RHNDA is clear on this. The law states this section shall not be construed to require an employer to provide insurance coverage related to a reproductive health decision.

There's absolutely no ambiguity here, it does not require pro-life organizations to hire individuals who advocate for abortion, it protects employees decisions regarding their own reproductive health, their beliefs about reproductive health are outside the scope of the law, organizations can still make employment decisions based on religion and political views, and employees must be willing to carry out employers' missions and directives.

I have some comments. I admire the fact that Mr. Joyce is going back to the drawing board. He's drawing on some of the knowledge of some of the people in the room here who are more professionally involved in these issues.

I am extremely uncomfortable about quite honestly moving forward on this. It is complicated and there is a gray area. Obviously, if there's a desire to have a vote, I personally think that this needs far more attention. I'm very uncomfortable about moving ahead on this. Just from listening to the members, I'm concerned about it and I'm sort of inclined quite honestly to ask you to withdraw your amendment and take it on for another day. But I want to be respectful obviously of the work and thought that's gone into this.

I think it's extremely complicated and I somewhat want to associate myself with Mr. Rogers. We are moving right into the -- in the area of authorization, the very type of authorization that many people criticize us on other parts of our bills. So, I'd like -- I'd ask that you consider withdrawing your amendment.

JOYCE: I've had the opportunity to -- been working on this since -- especially since Ohio has gotten involved into it. The answers to the questions that you raised are legitimate -- legitimate answers that we're going to find out.

I agree if Congress was doing their job. The authorized committees were doing their job. Maybe we do something. But that just hasn't occurred. And so, what we're trying to do is we're not changing the law. We're just asking for those who are trying to do what they find to be the wishes of their constituents since we are a body of representatives allowing that to take place in the -- what we would call the laboratories of our states both for medical marijuana and for democracy. They have chosen this route.

46 states have voted it in. We're just asking for them to have the opportunity if they see fit. Banks and credit unions don't have to do this. But those who want to engage in it will provide the buffer between us and the illegal remedies or the illegal dealers out there because they would have to verify that the funds coming in are coming from medical, medicinal facilities. They at least have the opportunity to engage if they want to and if they don't want to, fine. But that's what I'm asking for. That's why I think we'd like to move this one step forward and I would ask for a recorded vote -- or, no, not a recorded vote, excuse me, a voice vote because I know you want to get going, Mr. Chairman.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Ms. Kaptur?

KAPTUR: Yes. I just wanted to state something, because I'm not a doctor and I'm not a medical professional but obviously Ohio is like the number one state in deaths per capita related to opioid abuse and fentanyl, black tar heroin, all of it. And every...

JOYCE: Will the lady yield for a moment?

KAPTUR: I'll yield to the gentleman in a second. Every law enforcement officer I talk to, I ask about the pathway toward use. And to a person, as they have examined people who have died, there's an entry level experience and it begins with an M and it's not methamphetamine.

And so, I had the head of NIH to come in and see me because I said "I want you to give me the best information NIH has on what happens to the brain, to the patient, and inter-generationally to their children." And I said, "So, show me for long-term use of marijuana" and I'm not disagreeing with medical use of marijuana. I voted for that in the past. But, I said, "I want to know what happens to the brain where it happens. I want to know what happens with black tar heroin. I want to know what happens with cocaine. Every single addictive substance, I want to know what happens."

And thy began to show me maps of the brain and some of what they don't know which was shocking to me and they could not answer my questions definitively on long-term use of marijuana and increased amounts of use and then the pathway to something else and to look at what -- and they showed me what it takes to try to get someone off of an addictive substance like that and the numbers we have, we have approximately eight readmissions per patient that is heavily addicted, right, I'm not saying to marijuana, but other drugs that follow on and how difficult it is to try to unwind it in the brain and why. And they showed me MRIs of the brain.

What was shocking to me was after all these years, why can't medical science tell us exactly what happens to the brain and to the children of users? They can't answer that. So, it creates uncertainty in members who are not medical professionals who are trying to do the right thing for their constituents and for their country. But I just wanted to put that set of facts on the table because it made me very uncomfortable.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Further discussion on the Joyce amendment, Mr. Ryan?

RYAN: Mr. Chairman, I'd just like to add. I guess we could probably have this discussion in Ohio and leave everybody else out of it at this point. But, I just want to make the point that one of the concerns that I think a lot of us have is that we do have marijuana getting laced with all of these other drugs in them.

And where 30 years ago someone experimenting marijuana could now face -- laced with all of this horrible stuff that we're seeing in Ohio. I believe that the process here of moving towards both medical and overall legalization will provide safer, more controlled substances just like in alcohol. There are limited levels. It's controlled. As the gentleman from Nevada suggested, it's eventually taxed.

So, I just want to support this amendment, my friend from Ohio, and say that this is complicated. But I support him because this is the kind of thing that needs to get done. These things are helping save lives, improving the quality of life, and I just -- I wanted to add my support.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Thank you, Mr. Ryan.

Ms. Herrera Beutler is recognized.

HERRERA BEUTLER: I thank the chairman and the sponsor for working diligently on this. And like I said before, I think there are good people on both sides of this issue. This is not a cut and dry issue and I associate myself with the remarks of the former chairman and the current chairman in which, hey, surprise, surprise, guys, come on.

I really strongly believe that we're making -- it seems like a small thing and it was tailored and it was crafted tightly and I know that the staff and the teams working on this did everything they could. But the reality is, we are stepping into a place that we have no business stepping into. We have not done the hearings. We have not heard the testimony. We do not have the science. We do not have the background. Good or bad, we're appropriators. And in Labor H, we've had some of these conversations and I welcome more. Let's have more. Let's do it. Let's take it on.

But at 7:45 and we got this new amendment 10 minutes ago and we're debating a major change to federal policy here and now. I'm just saying it is, because when you open this door, the way this amendment was originally crafted was including recreational use, and that was not an accident, and I'm not saying that against the gentleman who offered it. I'm saying it against the people in the industry who is behind it.

The reason it was crafted that way is to allow banking -- federal banking for recreational use. And if we don't believe that, then, shoot, we fell off the turnip truck yesterday and I love that the chairman -- or the sponsor re-crafted it because I don't think that was his intent and the lady.

I don't think they're trying to do that. But the reality is, if we open this piece and we don't have all the background behind it, man, the litigation and the gray area that we're stepping into as appropriators, not as authorizers, is too much for this hour -- at this time and hour. And again, I just plead that we hit pause.

FRELINGHUYSEN: The gentleman from Texas, Judge Carter?

CARTER: Mr. Chairman, I very much admire...

FRELINGHUYSEN: Please give Judge Carter your attention. Thank you.

CARTER: This is going to be very brief. I very much admire his tenacity, but I want to go on record to say I'm voting no.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Further discussion? Let me say -- I ask the sponsor -- I would like you to withdraw your amendment. I'm asking you again to withdraw your amendment.

JOYCE: Well, I appreciate my former chairman and my chairman putting their foot down, I guess, and trying to make sure that I don't have enough votes to carry this forward. I appreciate the fact that you don't want to vote, but just for giggles maybe we might try a voice vote if the chairman would allow that and be satisfied with the results of said voice vote.

FRELINGHUYSEN: I'm asking you to withdraw your amendment.

JOYCE: I withdraw the amendment.

FRELINGHUYSEN: Any further amendments? If not -- the amendment is withdrawn.

If not, the gentleman from Kentucky is recognized for a motion.

Chairman Quigley, Ranking Member Graves and members of the Subcommittee, thank you for holding this hearing. My name is Rohit Chopra, and I'm honored to sit alongside Chairman Simons to represent the Federal Trade Commission.

Congressional oversight ensures that regulatory and enforcement agencies are accountable to the public. I welcome this oversight, and I believe it makes us stronger.

As Congress tackles some of the biggest challenges facing our economy, society, and even our national security, the Federal Trade Commission should be a critical piece of the puzzle. The stakes could not be higher. For example, how will we combat pharmaceutical industry abuses contributing to out-of-control drug prices that can mean the difference between life and death for patients? What can we do to make sure that Americans can get a pay raise in a competitive job market, rather than being squeezed by employer consolidation and non-compete agreements? How will we reverse the worrisome decline in new business formation and make sure that American entrepreneurs are not blocked by incumbents protecting their turf? How will we safeguard sensitive data from abuse and misuse by those here at home seeking profit and by those abroad seeking to do us harm? How will we deal with the rising dominance of Big Tech when it comes to fake reviews, facial recognition, fair competition, and so much more?

Congress is currently considering an increase in funding for the FTC, and I share Chairman Simons' commitment to use every resource effectively to deliver value for the public.

The FTC hearings that convened over the last year were a reminder of the importance of self-critical analysis. We must always be searching for ways to be more effective. For example, what more can we do to leverage the resources and authorities of our federal and state law enforcement partners to win full redress for victims and accountability for corporations and their executives that broke the law? How can we codify existing policy guidance and case law into clear rules so we can seek stiff penalties to be returned to taxpayers? What more can we do to protect honest businesses who play by the rules? We are actively thinking about new ways to use the authorities and resources that Congress has entrusted to the agency that solve problems in our markets.

We appreciate the opportunity to work with you to tackle these challenges and opportunities, and I look forward to responding to your questions.

House Appropriations Subcommittee On Financial Services And General Government Holds Hearing On Federal Trade Commission Oversight

September 25, 2019 10:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

REP. MIKE QUIGLEY (D-ILL.), CHAIRMAN

REP. JOSE E. SERRANO (D-N.Y.)

REP. MATT CARTWRIGHT (D-PA.)

REP. SANFORD D. BISHOP JR. (D-GA.)

REP. NORMA J. TORRES (D-CALIF.)

REP. CHARLIE CRIST (D-FLA.)

REP. ANN KIRKPATRICK (D-ARIZ.)

REP. NITA M. LOWEY (D-N.Y.), EX-OFFICIO

REP. TOM GRAVES (R-GA.), RANKING MEMBER

REP. MARK AMODEI (R-NEV.)

REP. CHRIS STEWART (R-UTAH)

REP. DAVID JOYCE (R-OHIO)

REP. KAY GRANGER (R-TEXAS), EX-OFFICIO

[*]QUIGLEY: Morning. Committee will come to order. Thank you for joining us today. I'm pleased to welcome Federal Trade Commission Chairman Joseph Simons and Commissioner Rohit Chopra, batting .100 so far. It is--okay--it's the Cubs I'm thinking of. It has been more than seven years since the FTC has appeared before this subcommittee, so gentlemen you're late. Now, it's long overdue and the FTC is obviously one of the most important agency the subcommittee funds, and it's only gotten more important over the last few years.

You have enormous jurisdiction policing most sectors of our economy for bad behavior. You cracked out on abusive robocallers, they investigate data breaches that expose sensitive personal information, they analyze consolidation in the health care market, help--helping to limit abusive pricing for essential drugs and health services. Perhaps, at the front of mine, they are the top cop on the beat for consumer privacy violations and other issues in the technology sector.

This is something everyone worries about these days; Democrat and Republican. Well, the tech companies are respecting the privacy choices of their customers whether they are choking off competition by favoring their own products or buying up competing products, we've seen some promising actions recently. The FTC certainly did not take a summer break.

In the past few months, they finalized high-profile settlements with Facebook, YouTube and Equifax. They launched an antitrust investigation on Facebook and possibly other companies. We recognize the challenges the FTC faces in policing such a large swath of the economy. That's why this year's House appropriation bill proposed a $40 million increase in FTC funding, that is a bump of more than 10 percent.

Part of the reason we're here is to understand how the FTC can invest these resources wisely; how they can get the best bang for the buck for consumers. It is also our duty as appropriators to determine if the FTC is using its existing resources as efficiently as possible. Consider this summer's Facebook settlement; yes, $5 billion is by far the largest private settle--privacy settlement but it doesn't seem to match the magnitude of the privacy violations.

That's--that fine does not represent even a full month of revenue for the company. It's not clear that the corporate changes, the FTC secured will head our future privacy violations. We could raise similar points about YouTube or questions why the Equifax settlement over one of the largest data breaches in history included only $31 million for alternative compensation.

The economy has transformed dramatically in the past decade. The companies we worry about today are structured much differently than the companies of concern in the past. What we want to know is this; can the FTC do better? Can it win bigger monetary settlements to provide greater redress to consumers or send clear signals to the market that the U.S. will not tolerate anti-competitive or deceptive behavior and that there will be severe consequences if that does happen.

We look forward to hearing from the Chairman and the Commissioner. Before I turn to the witnesses, I would like to recognize Mr. Graves for his opening remarks.

GRAVES: Mr. Chairman, and I appreciate you holding this hearing today. Mr. Chairman, thank you for being here and Commissioner as well. Before the hearing of your testimony and, you know, we--I think we all know that the Federal Trade Commission basically has two primary missions and the first is to protect consumers from unfair and deceptive and fraudulent practices as the chairman's discussed and this includes protecting Americans from identity theft, false advertising, those dreaded telemarketing calls, the unwanted telemarketing calls and certainly, scams against the most vulnerable or elderly internet that are in our communities and our great service members.

The FTC also make sure our markets are open and free. Mr. Chairman, I was thinking about your comments about it's been nearly seven years since they've been before us. There may be a reason for that and that since 2018, 95 percent, nearly 95 percent of all their decisions and their work on the Commission has been unanimous and we don't hear--hear a lot about that around here in a bipartisan way knowing that this is a--a bipartisan commission.

So congratulations to both of you on how you've worked together and I know there's still a 5 percent out there where there's tremendous debate and--and we expect that. But as we become more dependent on technologies in our everyday lives, these tasks are certainly more challenging that you face and--and some of them are thoughts that the chairman's brought up.

It's critically important though that technology companies that serve Americans act in an open and transparent manner, that the technology sector protects consumer privacy and that they do not conduct anti-competitive business practices whatsoever. And however, as a regulator of the FTC, must be careful not to stifle innovation while conducting its important work and I know it's a difficult balance that you--you grapple with every day because we've all seen in the past that over-regulation of industries can hurt the economic growth and ultimately can hurt consumers as well. So Mr. Chairman, well thank you for having this hearing today. I think it's going to be very informative and I appreciate the chairman for you joining us, and the commissioner as well and look forward to hearing your testimony.

QUIGLEY: Thank you, sir. I would now like to recognize the chairman for his testimony.

SIMONS: Thank you, Chairman Quigley, Ranking Member Graves, and members of the subcommittee. I am extremely pleased to be before you today to testify about the commission's work and funding requests, and particularly alongside my dear colleague, Commissioner Chopra.

The FTC is a highly effective independent agency with a broad mission as you said to protect consumers and maintain competition in most sectors of the economy. On the consumer protection side, we are aggressively pursuing law enforcement on privacy and data security matters including record-breaking settlements with Facebook, Google, and YouTube, and Equifax.

We've mainly used a 100 year old statute, Section 5 of the FTC Act to bring our privacy and data security actions, but our authority under Section 5 is limited. These limitations have a critical effect on our ability to protect consumers which is why we urge Congress to enact privacy and data security legislation enforceable by the FTC which grants us civil penalty authority targeted APA rulemaking authority and jurisdiction over nonprofits and common carriers.

In addition to privacy and data security cases, we continue to bring a broad range of enforcement actions addressing among other issues, fraud against older adults, service members and other diverse and underserved communities. On the competition side, enforcement actions in the pharmaceutical sector continue to be a big priority for us. Cases like our pay for delay matters protect generic competition which helps keep down drug prices.

To address concerns about the power of big tech, we have created a technology task force within the Bureau of Competition to concentrate our expertise and better investigate conduct by technology companies. I want to thank this committee for the additional $40 million for the FTC that is in the House Fiscal Year 2020 Financial Services and General Government appropriations bill. I assure you, we will make good use of that additional funding. Although, 40 million is a very large number, more than half of it might be needed to cover mandatory compensation increases, step increases, and non-compensation costs related to our agency operations such as our consumer, Sentinel Services contract, our litigation support service and our--an additional expert witness fees.

The remaining portion of the $40 million would likely be used for adding additional personnel in the neighborhood of 90 FTE. We would focus new staff additions to priority areas such as our privacy and enforcement divisions and the bureau of consumer protection, hiring more technologists, doubling the size of our technology task force and hiring more economists.

Finally, but significantly while principled differences among commissioners occasionally lead to split decision, some of them high-profile ones at that, the FTC predominantly works in a bipartisan fashion, and we will continue to do so.

We are committed to using every resource to effectively protect consumers and to promote competition and we look forward to continuing to work with the subcommittee and the Congress and I look forward to your questions. Thank you.

QUIGLEY: Thank you. Commissioner Chopra.

CHOPRA: All right. Thank you, Chairman Quigley, Ranking Member Graves and members of the subcommittee. I appreciate you holding this hearing today. My name is Rohit Chopra and I'm honored to sit alongside Chairman Simons to represent the Federal Trade Commission.

Congressional oversight ensures that regulatory and enforcement agencies are accountable to the public and I welcome this oversight. I know it makes agencies stronger and as Congress tackles some of the biggest challenges facing our economy, our society, and even our national security, the Federal Trade Commission should be a critical piece of that puzzle. The stakes simply could not be higher. For example, how are we going to combat pharmaceutical industry abuses that contribute to out-of-control drug prices? That mean the difference between life and death for patients.

What can we do to make sure that Americans can get a fair pay raise in a competitive job market rather than being squeezed by employer consolidation and non-compete agreements? How are we going to reverse the worrisome decline in new business formation and make sure that American entrepreneurs are not blocked by incumbents protecting their turf? How will we safeguard sensitive data from abuse and misuse by those here at home seeking profit and by those abroad seeking to do--seeking to do us harm?

How will we deal with the rising dominance of big tech when it comes to fake reviews, facial recognition, fair competition, and so much more. Congress is currently considering an increase in funding for the FTC and I share the Chairman's commitment to use every resource effectively so that we deliver real value for the public. The FTC hearings that convened over the last year were reminder of the importance of self-critical analysis.

We must always be searching for ways to be more effective. For example, what can we do to leverage the resources and authorities of our federal and state law enforcement partners to win full redress for victims and accountability for corporations and their executives that broke the law? How can we codify existing policy guidance and case line to clear rules so we can seek stiff penalties to be returned to taxpayers?

What more can we do to protect honest businesses who play by the rules but are harmed by those who cheat? We are actively thinking about new ways to use the authorities and resources that Congress has entrusted to the agency that solve real problems in our markets. We appreciate the opportunity to work with you to tackle these challenges and opportunities and I look forward to your questions.

QUIGLEY: Thank you both and again, thank you both for being here. Commissioner, you and your fellow Democratic commissioner dissented in the YouTube and Facebook settlements. Could you give us a deeper dive as to the reasoning for your dissent and what you think the FTC can do differently or better to address these issues?

CHOPRA: Sure. The Facebook corporation is a major governance and managerial challenge facing every regulator in the globe. They have serious dysfunction and they repeatedly violated the 2012 FTC order almost immediately. I was not happy with the outcome of the settlement. I think that it provided blanket releases of claims that were unspecified. There was not a deep--

QUIGLEY: It's not just the money or is money part of it?

CHOPRA: Well it--will--will $5 billion while it is a record, is it going to change a firm that makes that amount of money very, very quickly? This is one of the largest corporations in the world and Wall Street reacted, they didn't actually find it that big of a deal. Most in Silicon Valley who analyzed that business didn't see it as so significant. So for me, I outlined all of these concerns and look, since the time we finalized that settlement, we've now heard of more and more problems.

You know, just recently, just a few days ago 64,000 apps suspended, we learned from the Massachusetts attorney general court filings, you know, we learn about phone numbers. I mean, it just keeps going and going and I am concerned that the core problems in that firm are not fixed.

QUIGLEY: Mr. Chairman, I would ask your thoughts on that settlement and so--and more importantly, the ongoing issue that that settlement was discussing. And--and if you could add into this discussion, if what--if these decisions and settling are because of a risk of losing in court and is there something we can do to mitigate against that concern?

SIMONS: In this case, I don't think it had anything to do really with the risk of losing in court. Just to give some context, we do not have the authority ourselves to fine people. We have to go to court and get a court to agree to the fine and to any other additional injunctive relief. So in this case, I think there's a widespread view that if we had gone to court, if we had spent years in litigation and if we had won, the relief that we achieved in the settlement was far greater than any court would have likely granted us.

So in terms of whether--whether, you know, the settlement or going to litigation was the right choice, I know--I think it's really clear. The settlement was far greater than we could have gotten in litigation and it's--there are now under--well actually, hopefully soon, they will be under order when the court signs the--the papers and finalizes it. And once that happens, then they're under a much sti--stiffer regime than they were previously.

The other thing I would say is two, is in terms of the five billion, that is about 22 or 23 percent of their profits from last year. I mean, taking--taking that much of someone's profit is--is, you know, should be making them think about how they run their business.

QUIGLEY: Is there something besides the fines though that can change behavior and I--I just want you to elaborate on that.

SIMONS: Yeah, yeah, absolutely. So part of this, another--another big part of this settlement is the injunctive relief. So we've done a whole bunch of things there. We've got--we've got a new committee of the board that's formed that deals solely with privacy and is only composed of independent directors, we've got a requirement on Mr. Zuckerberg that he certify quarterly that they are in compliance with--with the privacy program that's mandated in the order. He can't--he can't just stick his head in the sand. He gets mandatory information flows which--which he has to review.

There's a very beefed up third-party assessor that's in here, we have the ability to hire and fire. That assessor has access to these mandatory information flows that the order requires. And then, the FTC itself has the ability to monitor too more stringently than we have had in the past.

QUIGLEY: Thank you. Mr. Graves.

GRAVES: Mr. Chairman, I--I know we'll talk a little bit more about antitrust and Facebook and others but something is a little bit more pressing for me is--because we've been hearing a lot about it in the news lately is SIM swapping. And this--this is when a bad actor, you know, pretends to be somebody calls a--a telecommunications company and--and convinces them to activate a SIM card on a different device and then that allows them to basically have mobile identity theft and have access to a person's phone oftentimes, bank accounts, their applications, passwords, all those change things.

And what's interesting is that the--the FTC actually responded to this over three years ago and there's a--a blog that was posted about this very thing. But it seems to be intensifying and--and more active. In fact, Jack Dorsey who suffered this just a few weeks ago himself and--and his phone was taken over. Can you give us an update what--what role do you have in--in this and what can consumers do to protect themselves from this and Mr. Chairman, I'll start--start with you on that if you don't mind.

SIMONS: Yeah, so--so we share your concerns. This--this is--this is a big problem and it enables fraudsters to access consumers text messages and phone calls as you said, get information, personal information, get--potentially get into their bank accounts and other--other important aspects of their personal lives. So this is--this is--this is a--this is a serious problem.

We--we did provide and do provide on our website guidance to the consumers on this issue and we continue--we continue to monitor this issue very--very carefully. So this is--this is something we're--we're--we're focused on.

CHOPRA: The only thing I'll add is that as two-factor authentication spreads which is generally a good thing, most people are using that through their personal cell phone and so obviously, that's now a big vulnerability, the more someone can dig into that phone. So for me, I think of this broader issue of identity theft as really, problems in our data security infrastructure and that has huge impacts on Commerce, national security, everything. So if we don't take this seriously, the--we can't quantify the harm that can come from this.

GRAVES: So the--but the two-step verification doesn't really stop a SIM swap--

CHOPRA: No--no but it makes it--

GRAVES: It might help with an application or--or such.

SIMONS: It makes it more damaging, right.

GRAVES: It doesn't stop from reading somebody's text messages, changing passwords out on a cell phone and other things. What--what can the federal government do to protect consumers from this and--and I guess that's my basic--I think--I think consumers are doing everything they can, you know, technology is moving very rapidly, they're trying to protect their own identity but now, some of our telecommunications companies are inadvertently giving out personal information.

SIMONS: Maybe there's something we could do in terms of encouraging the carriers because a lot of--a lot of what enables this, right, is that the--the--the carrier--the--the scammer--the--the fraudster is able to get enough information that when you go through the security questions, they're able to answer them. And so, maybe we need--we need to--we need to think about how to--how to make that more secure.

GRAVES: Yeah, thank you and Mr. Chairman, if I could, I have one other question related because another issue that sort of been on my mind a little bit--as a relationship, chairman and I both have this similar position about cybersecurity and some of the threats we--we face as it relates to protection of privacy, that's why I'm bringing up SIM swaps.

But we had an FTC meeting recently that discussed geo location data being shared by--being sold from these same companies without a consumer's knowledge as well. The FTC has some jurisdiction here as--as well to take action against those that are engaged in these unfair deceptive practices. Can you give us an update as to what involvement you have in that area too, Mr. Chairman?

SIMONS: Sure, I'd be happy to. So--so we're extremely concerned about this area as well. Location information is particularly sensitive because it's autho--it-- its unauthorized sharing can create safety concerns, stalking for example. We do not have the jurisdiction to bring cases against common carriers and we--we've asked for that--that immunity to be reversed and for us to have jurisdiction.

But we have brought several cases alleging un--unfair and deceptive practices in connection with--with this problem. For example, we alleged that a popular flashlight app shared information with ad networks without disclosing the fact first. This was the Goldenshores case and we have several non-public investigations going on right now regarding this issue.

GRAVES: Okay. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

QUIGLEY: Ms. Torres.

TORRES: Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and Ranking Member, Commission Chopra, thank you for being here. In your dissenting statement in the YouTube settlement, you noted the Commission already has a--has strong authority over children's privacy under the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act but has failed to use the enforcement tools at its disposal to effectively deter actions that infringe on children's right to privacy.

So I was very surprised to learn that on Monday, FTC officials actually suggested weakening restrictions on how data can be collected from users who watch videos aimed at children. How would this move impact children's privacy and legal protections under the law--current law?

CHOPRA: Well, this--I have not re--reviewed the statement that was made by him but I don't know, he does not speak for me or any other individual commissioner. I do not agree that we should be, you know, moving toward any sort of weakness. We are doing a review and if we do weaken the rule in a harmful way, that's not something I would want to support and obviously, Congress will have to review that and has the right under the Congressional Review Act to overturn it.

So I think we should go into it, looking for ways to actually make sure protections are stronger and that we can have the tools to deter the worst type of behavior because we are already seeing how mass accumulation of data on children is so lucrative, but it also can be extremely harmful and misused and--and we should take that very seriously.

TORRES: I haven't seen so many abuses at every level specifically as it relates to foster children and, you know, being a--a grandma of a four-year-old, I want to make sure that this issue doesn't, you know, go by the wayside. We have to do everything that we can to protect the future of children and their identities.

California Consumer Privacy Act, CCPA is consider the most expensive privacy law in the country. It will take effect in January 1st, 2020. Congress and state legislators are working on legislation that would provide baseline consumer privacy protections in the US. Have you reviewed the California law?

CHOPRA: Yes, I have.

TORRES: And are there any elements of that law that you think should be adopted at the federal level?

CHOPRA: Well, there's a lot of details to the law but just some things that come to mind. There's a very clear way of deterring and penalizing firms that engage in violations and there's a different level of penalty for willful or intentional violations compared to unintentional ones. I think making sure that there's clear liability for those who violate the law will create the incentives in the market to actually protect data and not abuse it. There's also some new consumer rights that are part of it.

I think all of that is good but we also need to make sure we're looking at how to attack the underlying incentive that is about going to--relates to collecting geolocation data. All of this data is monetized and that's the business model that is impacting so many of our problems online.

TORRES: It's--this is an issue that is--it's zero tolerance. If you accidentally swipe your card and know that there's zero balance on your checking account, the bank is not forgiving and says, it's your first mistake, we're going to waive all fees, the credit companies don't give you a break. You're punished by it and it should be in the same line; zero tolerance for that.

The FTC often works with state attorney generals on cases. Will the California law or other state privacy laws impact the Commission's work in any way?

CHOPRA: I'm happy that--I always think it's good when state AGs are with us. They often have authorities and ability to pen--get penalties. So for me I'm really encouraging more state action when it comes to going after some of the abuses in the tech area. So--and we're seeing more laws being passed and that's going to give us more leverage at the table. But obviously, a federal law will help us as well.

TORRES: And--and just really briefly, you probably won't have time but I just want to put this on the record for you. In recent years, consumers have reported an increase in online hotel booking scams when third-party vendors falsely claim to be affiliated with or proprietors of a hotel. So I'm curious to know what actions the FTC has taken to combat these scams as an issue that comes up often in my district. so, you know, same as Facebook, zero tolerance, and this is the same type of issue where you have like pages.

CHOPRA: So it's--oh, go ahead. It's obviously a problem and these types of scams, one of my concerns is that they are heavily facilitated by some of the advertising models of the larger firms because they don't really police a lot of this content. SIMONS: Yeah. So this is a--this is a big area of emphasis for us. We have a whole unit that is devoted to looking at anti-competitive conduct in this--in this space. GRAVES: Great.

CHOPRA: It--these firms, I think six or seven of the ten largest publicly-traded--I'm sorry, seven ten largest corporations in the world are--are Chinese or US tech companies. JOYCE: What type of anti-competitive behavior have you seen when you look into these big tech companies?

SIMONS: Well, we can't really talk about any specific investigation. But one of the main things you might look for is a situation where the platform is engaged in some kind of exclusionary conduct particularly against a company that might not be a direct competitor immediately but might turn into one. An example of this is what history kind of like repeats itself in cycles. So an example of this from the past would have been Microsoft and--and the--their anti-competitive behavior rating--relating to Netscape's browser.

CHOPRA: I would also add--

JOYCE: I was old enough to remember that one.

CHOPRA: I would also add looking closely at past mergers, joint ventures; to what extent was the purchase of many, many firms part of--a potentially a way to eliminate a potential competitor or maintain a monopoly. That has to be--that's always part of how effective antitrust enforcement should look at things. It's not just looking at mergers before they're consummated it's also looking at them after to determine was it part of a plan to essentially shut down a potential threat.

SIMONS: You can imagine a situation in which the--the plan is to try to buy the companies that are the most threatening. SIMONS: Yeah, exactly. SIMONS: Yeah, it could be. Yeah, it depends on the situation. Sometimes--sometimes, you know, like these robocalls are just scams and they're coming from foreign countries but sometimes they're coming from inside the country. And one of the reasons we want to go after the--the carriers who are taking the calls and putting them into the U.S. telephone system is just for this reason; They're out of--the--the--the fraudster themselves actually is out of reach and but we can get to the carrier and stop them from facilitating the fraud.

JOYCE: For what it's worth, every time I've done one of these education processes at senior centers, all of them I've reached have gotten these calls.

SIMONS: Yeah, oh yeah, absolutely.

CHOPRA: Yeah, we also need--we need push the carriers writ large on a lot of these types of problems. I think they have evaded a lot of scrutiny when it comes to their role in this.

QUIGLEY: Thank you Mr. Joyce. Thank you, Mr. Graves and our colleagues for their thoughtful questions. Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, thank you so much for being here. We appreciate that, we appreciate your service, we'll see you soon, thank you. This meeting is adjourned.

SIMONS: Thank you.
